learning_obj.text: Understanding how to compare multiple design alternatives objectively
Applying a structured approach to select the best option among alternatives
Recognizing how to improve or combine ideas repeatedly
Communicating decisions with data-driven justification, not just intuition

characteristics.text: Compares multiple options against a baseline
Uses + / 0 / – to rate performance relative to baseline
Based on defined evaluation criteria (e.g., cost, quality)
Can be weighted to reflect importance
Produces a simple, visual matrix to support clear decisions
Versatile (deciding between new location for office, hiring candidates, marketing campaign strategies, data platforms, etc.)

sub_bullets.text: Clearly state what decision you are trying to make (ex. “Select the best site for a new clinic”).
Identify all possible options or designs (ex. Site A, Site B, Site C).
Determine the factors that matter (ex. cost, accessibility, environmental impact, timeline).
Select one option as a reference point for comparison — typically the current or most familiar one.
For each criterion, compare the alternative to the baseline using:
Count the number of +, 0, and – for each option.
Identify high-scoring alternatives. If none are ideal, consider combining features or refining criteria and repeat.
Choose the best-performing alternative or shortlist top candidates for further analysis.

benefits.text: Structured decision-making: reduces bias and emotions in choices
Simple visualization: easy to communicate results
Encourages teamwork: groups can evaluate collaboratively
Facilitates iteration: can improve ideas over multiple rounds
Flexible: works for both qualitative and quantitative data
Worthwhile Development: allows inclusion of criteria related to well-being and environmental effects, focusing on ethics in comparative processes

drawbacks.text: Subjective: scoring “+” or “–” depends on judgment
No weighting by default: unless you assign weights, all criteria are treated equally
Baseline sensitivity: results can vary if the reference option changes
Not purely quantitative: less precise for data-heavy or financial decisions

example.text: Choose the best LMS platform for a university to support online courses, grading, and student engagement

sub_bullets.text: Integration with university systems (SIS, email, etc.)
Canvas (A2) has the highest overall score (+19), indicating it outperforms the baseline across most criteria
Moodle (A3) improves on cost and customization but lacks in integration, support, and compliance, limiting institutional scalability
Google Classroom (A4) performs well in cost and simplicity but poorly in integration, security, and support
Canvas’s only real weakness is higher licensing cost, but it provides superior functionality and reliability
Delivers the best combination of usability, support, and integration even after weighting adjustments

evaluation.text: Can you assign weights to your criteria?
Can you determine which alternative is best or worst simply by looking at your chart?
